_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary

Environmental and Safety Policy:
It is the policy of Heritage Thermal Services, Inc. (HTS) to conduct itself as a good corporate citizen, to be a responsible member of the region's industrial community, and to comply with all federal, state, and local environmental laws and regulations.  HTS strives continuously to maintain safe operations and implements safe operating procedures in all processes at the facility. 

HTS practices a proactive approach with respect to communications with East Liverpool and neighboring communities.   The facility's Web Site (http://www.heritage-thermal.com) provides information on safety, environment, training, plant improvements, tours, and other pertinent information. Meetings are held as requested with one local citizens group (East Liverpool Environmental Committee) for updates on plant operations, permitting, and safety.  Communication channels also are established through participation of facility employees in local civic organizations such as the Kiwanis, Rotary, and Lions.  

In short, HTS maintains safe operations at the facility and practices open communication with the local community, many of whom are employees of the facility.

Facility Operations and Setting:
HTS operates a hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility (TSDF) in East Liverpool, Ohio.  Solid and liquid wastes within permit specifications are received in the facility and thermally treated in a rotary kiln incinerator. The facility has a final permit status under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act of 1976 (RCRA).  HTS was purchased in full by Heritage Environmental Services, LLC and removed the name Von Roll from all company documents in 2008. The facility began doing business as Heritage-WTI, Inc. at that time. In 2013, the company changed its name to Heritage Thermal Services.

Wastes are received at the facility in liquid, solid, and semi-solid form in packages (lined boxes, fiber packs, metal cans, drums,

and reusable containers) or in bulk (dump trucks or tank wagons).  The wastes are pre-approved and registered in a computerized tracking system.  Upon arrival, the wastes are weighed and the associated paperwork reviewed to verify compliance with regulatory requirements.  The wastes are sampled and, after approval, directed to the appropriate process treatment area.  Bulk solids are emptied directly into storage pits, then transferred into the feed hopper of the kiln by a clamshell bucket crane.  Bulk liquid wastes are unloaded under a roof in a contained, concrete area. The tankers are purged with nitrogen.  Fugitive emissions are captured and vented to the incinerator or treated through activated carbon units.  Limited types of bulk liquid wastes are pumped directly to the kiln from the tankers.  Drummed wastes are processed under a roof in the drum processing building.  Organic waste blending occurs in an indoor tank farm.  

All waste handling, storage, and treatment areas are in concrete containment and utilize collection sumps to capture any spilled materials.  In addition, overhead ventilation hoods that vent to the incinerator or activated carbon units, service all handling areas.

The facility is located approximately 30 miles northwest of Pittsburgh, Pa., on the Ohio River in East Liverpool, Columbiana County, Ohio.  The facility is located directly across the Ohio River from West Virginia and less than one-half mile from the Pennsylvania-Ohio border. The area in the immediate vicinity is mixed residential and commercial, with some light industrial activity present.  The facility is situated on a 21.5 acre tract.  The site is bordered on the north by Norfolk Southern railroad tracks, on the east by Growmark, an agricultural services company, on the south by the Ohio River, and on the west by the Columbiana County Port Authority . The area immediately surrounding these properties is zoned medium-high density residential use.  

The topography of the

area is gently rolling, except in the immediate vicinity of the site where the Ohio River forms a steep river valley.  Considering the local and regional topographic elevations near the site, it is likely that the winds will be channeled along the valley, with predominant wind flow to the east-northeast.  The closest incorporated areas to the facility include East Liverpool, Ohio; Chester, WV; Wellsville, Ohio; and Midland, Pa.  

Regulated Substance(s):
All chemicals at the facility are received from waste generators around the nation.  The facility receives wastes from various generators and the constituents of the wastes vary.  It is impossible for HTS to predict the type of waste entering the facility.  However, only wastes conforming to pre-selected profiles are accepted at the facility.  The waste profiles include constituents and ranges of percentage of the constituents.  The waste profiles are the basis of determining the regulated substances for the Risk Management Program.

Based on a comprehensive review of waste profiles received at the facility in the calendar year 1998, the following 32 regulated substances could be reasonably expected to be present at the facility at any given time above the threshold quantity (TQ) established pursuant to the Risk Management Program (RMP):

Acetaldehyde, Acrylonitrile, Carbon disulfide, Chloroform, Crotonaldehyde, Epichlorohydrin, Ethylenediamine, Ethyleneimine, Formaldehyde (solution), Furan (30%), Hydrazine, Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric  acid (conc 50% or greater), Isobutyronitrile,  Methacrylonitrile, Methyl hydrazine, Methyltrichlorosilane, Peracetic acid, Phosphorus oxychloride,  Phosphorus trichloride, Piperidine, Propionitrile, Propyleneimine, Propylene oxide, Sulfur trioxide, Titanium tetrachloride, Toluene 2,4-diisocyanate, Trimethylchlorosilane, Vinyl acetate monomer, Ethyl ether, Pentane, Trichlorosilane, and Vinylidene chloride.            
     
The regulated substances are present in five proc

esses, which are currently in operation at the facility: 1.) the organic tank farm; 2.) the drum storage area; 3.) the pump-out/blend tanks; 4.) the drum conveying area; and 5.) direct tanker unloading. 
 
Accident Prevention Program:
The HTS facility has developed and implemented a PSM program for the processes covered by the RMP.  HTS performs daily, monthly, and annual inspections of all process components.  Safe operating procedures are regularly reviewed and updated whenever necessary.  The operators are regularly trained on handling wastes in the various process areas and on emergency response actions.  Deluge systems are installed at all possible areas of release to contain fires. In addition, any release within the buildings is vented to the incinerator or activated carbon system, which operates continuously. Fire suppression systems are installed in all process areas and direct communication is maintained through an automated alarm system at the facility and monitored by the local fire department.

In November 1998, HTS became the first commercial hazardous waste incineration facility to obtain certification to the ISO 14001 standard, the international standard for environmental management.  To complement this certification, HTS also obtained certification in the ISO 9001 Standard, the international standard for quality management.   As part of the process, HTS has critically reviewed safety and health issues at the facility.   The ISO certification demonstrates HTS's commitment to the employees and the community by maintaining safety, the environment and quality in our operations and in customer service. HTS has further strengthened this commitment by achieving OHSAS 18001 certification in August of 2009. OHSAS 18001 is an international occupational health and safety management system specification.

Five-year Accident History:
There have been no accidental releases from any of the covered processes at the facility in the last five years, which mee

t the reporting criteria of the RMP.  HTS is committed to maintaining this safety record.

Emergency Response Program: 
The emergency plan includes emergency and incident notification, reporting, emergency health care, emergency response actions, training and drills, and an incident prevention program, which fulfills all requirements of RMP.  Emergency response training is part of the plan and the most recent training was performed in March 2014.  The facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the East Liverpool Fire Department. The plan was updated in May of 2014 and will be updated whenever there are changes at the facility that may impact emergency response actions.  In addition, extensive training is performed for onsite emergency response and maintenance of the onsite fire brigade. Copies of the plan are made available to the county LEPC and city fire department.

Planned Safety Improvements:
HTS believes that the processes at the facility are operated and maintained in a safe manner.  Improving safety is continuously ongoing at the facility and our highest priority. HTS plans to take all necessary, realistic, technical, and economically feasible actions to improve safety, whenever determined to be necessary.
